nodes.bodyText: This is a bit scary to me. Is there no normal AWS SDK client that does this?
I couldnt find a normal sdk client which has abstraction for accepting a device certificate for HTTP. This is also similar to how MQTT client does TLS in iot device sdk.

Does this really require a threadpool? Seems like a regular HTTP request shouldn't need extra threads, it can just use the main thread. In subsequent PRs let's move to Apache HTTP client and use a Java keystore.
Yes. Ideally we should not be using extra threads here, dont see a need. Lets have more discussion around this.
dont put the {} here. The exception will be used and not interpolated into the string.
Ok
Yikes. If this really needs to be this low level, I'm quite concerned.
Yup. Will try to confirm, but could not find anything more abstract.
Instead of writing our own, have you tried to use Apache HTTP client? Would that be simpler?
Or use Apache HTTP Core? https://hc.apache.org/httpcomponents-core-ga/index.html

Problem is that all(yet to see an exception) java libraries rely on SSLContext to specify client certificates. For instance Apache Http client uses the same: https://svn.apache.org/viewvc/httpcomponents/oac.hc3x/trunk/src/contrib/org/apache/commons/httpclient/contrib/ssl/AuthSSLProtocolSocketFactory.java?view=markup
SSLContext relies on Java key store interface for specifying keys/certs. Trying custom auth implementation would be more tricky(mucking with security?), like letting SSLContext depend on our custom file based key or cert. I can dig in more to see if there are more options. Other thing was trying to avoid dependencies additionally, we are already using the IOT device sdk for MQTT connection to cloud, so this does not bring anything additional.
Also, once running, you need to set the environment variables appropriately so that services know how to contact you.
I was under the impression that kernel has to do it. This is really nice.
definitely seems too long

For using apache client. I think we should minimize northbound connections to cloud. The higher abstractions you choose the more difficult it would be to optimize those cases. I will leave this open for discussion for now, but ideally greengrass should minimize connections for all HTTP traffic northbound unless specified by the customer. On the same lines TES should make sure that only one connection is made northbound, and all in flight requests wait. With multiple threads you risk opening connections as many concurrent requests you get. TES would not be performance constrained as anyway clients would also cache credentials especially if they are using SDK. Lets discuss more on this later.

I don't know how true it is. But I went through a security review before and was told not to use String to store creds in memory. Use Byte[] instead. I remember the reason was due to String objects stay in memory longer.
